content.intro:
Just above the equator, you can encounter the heart of Africa, a heart whose vibrations you'll hear as you land in Douala, a heart that beats to the rhythm of makossa, this cross of rumba and mambo. Stretching from the Atlantic Ocean to Lake Chad, the land of Cameroon offers a breath-taking escape.

For the ‘River of the Shrimp' (Rio dos Camarões) as Portuguese explorers called it, there is not one capital, but two: Douala, the principal commercial city and Yaoundé, the political and cultural centre. On the shores of the Wouri river, Douala is in a constant race to construct its own future. Here is where business in Cameroon was born, on its banks, in its ports. It is here that the Cameroon of tomorrow is evolving, the country that is already the top economic power in French-speaking central Africa.

Poised and thoughtful on its seven hills, Yaoundé is tranquil and amiable, leading the nation in political diplomacy and culture. The city is the high place for the heritage of some 200 ethnic groups that make up the people of one of the greenest countries on the continent, both ecological and untouched. Imagine a land with 30 natural parks and the most beautiful reserves of butterflies, rare woods and monkeys. You can indeed breathe in the jungle, touch it and hear it…

In 1998, barely 78 visitors had pushed open the door of the Ecotourism Office in Buéa, a pioneering structure in Cameroon. Now, almost twenty years later, ecotourism is no longer considered an intrusion, because it shows respect. The Office knows how to make sure communities benefit from new equipment and infrastructure. Though colonialists left their architectural heritage, with the German lighthouse of Kribi, the French villa of Mundemba or Foulassi, and the English church, these remnants live alongside a history thousands of years old. But it is not in capitals with galloping demographics that the past will be evident. Leave Douala or Yaoundé on excursions to other landscapes. Dive deep into the décor of traditional tales. Nothing has disturbed nor will disturb the chefferie of Bafut in Bamenda, or the village of Nkolandom in Centre South of Cameroon, which means ‘mount of elegance' in Bulu. Elegance, indeed, is the perfect definition for Cameroon and Cameroonian.

content.title: Le C celebrates French-Cameroonian cuisine

introduction.small: Ideally located in the Bonapriso neighbourhood in Douala, Le C conveys a zen and trendy atmosphere in an Asian-influenced decor around a French-Cameroonian menu.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le C celebrates French-Cameroonian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
A gigantic statue of Buddha takes centre stage and other items depicting the icon have been scattered here and there, giving the decor some chic Balinese look, enhanced by subdued lighting and tall bamboo. But make no mistake, Le C – C as in Cameroon – reveals fusion gastronomy that blends traditional Cameroonian and French recipes.
For pre-dinner drinks, head to the lounge bar for cocktails or a glass of wine from the restaurant's cellar, to be enjoyed in moderation, comfortably sitting on one of the mellow brown sofas. Choose a dish among the various options on the menu, or the daily specials displayed on a blackboard: barracuda fillets flavoured with white, green and black pepper, vanilla-caramelised plantain, marinated chicken skewers with hot pepper and paprika, served with biryani rice, or why not the grilled Cameroonian king prawns and sweet potato gratin in curry. A local must-go-to for a gustatory journey across the world.

Le C
99, rue Tokoto
Douala

+237 6 96 82 79 72

www.facebook.com/clerestaurant/ ﻿

Menu: around 19,000 XAF

content.title: Kajazoma, between a restaurant and an art gallery

introduction.small: An atypical restaurant that is also an art gallery, Kajazoma is a must for drinks or dinner in Yaoundé.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kajazoma, between a restaurant and an art gallery

paragraphs.text:
In Yaoundé's posh Bastos neighbourhood, Kajazoma attracts art enthusiasts and food lovers alike, for this hybrid establishment is at once a restaurant, an art gallery and a show room. In a chic ethnic decor, African Art is given prominence, with contemporary paintings, as well as sculptures and jewels sourced locally, but also in Mali and Ivory Coast.
In the back of the restaurant, a large and lush garden turns into a lounge space every Friday and Saturday night, to the pace of jazz concerts. On the food side, the menu draws inspiration from French-Cameroonian gastronomy. Expect rolled sole fillets in curry, king prawn pasta or an emperor fish in Parma style. Look around you during the meal, as everything is for sale. From furniture to decoration items and household linens, there is something to satisfy all bargain-hunters.

Kajazoma
Bastos
Behind the Belgian Embassy

www.facebook.com/Kajazoma-490226287795407

Menu: around 15,000 XAF

content.title: La Fourchette: quality cuisine!

introduction.small: This restaurant is a hit for its French cuisine and bar lounge with a pleasant garden and for aficionados, Cuban cigars.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Fourchette: quality cuisine!

paragraphs.text:
At noon, the management of the neighbouring banks come here to lunch. Attached to the Afriland First Bank, La Fourchette is their favourite canteen at noon. In the evening, they may even come back with friends to enjoy a cocktail in one of the many cosy armchairs in the lounge. The atmosphere is casual, with relaxing background music.

Scallops stuffed with crab, leg of lamb or a fish filet, the menu offers cuisine with French accents. It is the reference by which they go. If Douala residents appreciate the restaurant so much, it is because the dishes are delicious, generous, and the preparation perfect, but also because it is a tradition that every dinner ends with a Cuban cigar. Indeed, the bartender offers an incredible selection. And all are Made in Cuba!

La Fourchette
Rue du Prince de Galles
Douala

+237 699 92 64 66

Menu: around 14,600 XAF

content.title: Hotel Mont Fébé: the historical hotel of Yaoundé

introduction.small: On one of the seven hills of Yaoundé, at 950 metres of altitude, in the middle of a luxurious park, the Hotel Mont Fébé shows off its vintage architecture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Mont Fébé: the historical hotel of Yaoundé

paragraphs.text:
This hotel has a unique charm, with its modern architecture it looks like it is straight out of a movie set. Five minutes from the presidential palace and the Embassy of the United States, it is much appreciated for its peace and the security it enjoys. Indeed, in addition to its 218 comfortable rooms and 18 suites, the Hotel Mont Fébé has a VIP floor coveted for official trips.

If you are staying here as part of your business trip, you will enjoy its gym to keep in shape. Yaoundé residents appreciate its golf course and tennis courts, but also its grill restaurant, the Rondo. Cameroonian cuisine or international choices are available for you to choose, but also take time in the evening for a cocktail with music playing at the Abbia, the most popular bar in town.

Hôtel Mont Fébé

content.title: All of Cameroon's heritage at the National Museum

introduction.small: After several years being renovated, the emblematic National Museum opens again. It covers the entire history of the country, from the arrival of Portuguese sailors till now.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: All of Cameroon's heritage at the National Museum

paragraphs.text:
The Governor of Yaoundé's palace was transformed into the presidential one. The National Museum then took up the spot and launched renovation works in 2009. Since it opened again in January of 2015, this 5,000 m2 area has found a new life.

The museum acquired several hundreds of rare and traditional items to offer Cameroonian culture a wide range of expression, exalting in the unity and grandeur of the country.

Before you even set foot in this splendid museum, you will be impressed by the series of bronze statues which dress the front yard and pay tribute to the bamoun people. Once inside, you will enjoy wandering through huge areas that present relics of an ancient lifetime (music instruments, kitchen utensils…), attributes of traditional nobility – especially the ngii, a tribal wooden mask – but also portraits of celebrities who have made the political and cultural history of Cameroon since its Independence.

Musée National du Cameroun

content.title: Star Land Hotel at the centre of the business area

introduction.small: This new address has fast become the must-go-to hotel for business travellers and lovers alike, seduced by the warm service of the hotel staff and high-end performances.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Star Land Hotel at the centre of the business area

paragraphs.text:
Located in the heart of the Bonapriso neighbourhood, one of the most beautiful and residential areas in Douala, and only 5 minutes from both the airport and downtown, the Star Land Hotel offers a wide ranging selection of clear and spacious rooms (from 28 to 85 m2).

Relax under a shower in your private marble bathroom with a “rain effect” and enjoy a cocktail in one of the two bars on the premises: the cosy Land, which opens onto the swimming pool, or the Sky Bar and its panoramic terrace which offers a jazz atmosphere on every Thursday.

Each area can be reserved for private events and seminars. The Star Land Hotel offers three fully air-conditioned and equipped working environments of 35 to 200 m2.

And do not hesitate to stop at Le Gourmet, the hotel restaurant which offers 24/7 service, as well as buffet formulas for breakfast and dinner.

content.title: Foumban, the city of art

introduction.small: This chefferie, 250 kilometres northwest of Yaoundé, is the capital of the Bamoun kingdom, still led by the descendants of King Njoya and reachable by bus and bush taxi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Foumban, the city of art

paragraphs.text:
Foumban is one of the oldest cities of Cameroon. The city dates to 1394, when it was established as the centre of the Bamileke dynasty. One of the most famous kings was Ibrahim Njoya, who reigned from 1887 to 1933 and created everything from a syncretic religion including elements of Islam, Christianity and animism, to a secret language and an alphabet of 83 letters. You can admire his statue in front of the palace, designated a UNESCO world heritage site, that was constructed in his name, a building that resembles a medieval castle with towers at the corners.

The 12,500 magnificent pieces of art are on display at the Musée Royal nearby. The street of the artisans leads from the palace to the museum. Along this street you will be able to buy souvenirs such as embroidered fabrics and basketry. Indeed, the Bamileke are noted artisans, among the best in the country, and their creations are worthy of their reputation.

content.title: Doual'art: the headquarters of urbanites

introduction.small: When in Douala, don't miss the opportunity of supporting contemporary artists at this centre's exhibits and lectures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Doual'art: the headquarters of urbanites

paragraphs.text:
Doual'art is the only volunteer-run centre in Douala dedicated to modern art. Housed in a wing of the old pagoda, it has a garden café where you can enjoy a tea or iced lemonade in the dry season. Exhibitions are regularly scheduled here, but the team also promotes a contemporary urban culture and the preservation of the historical heritage of the city.

This is a place that will make you see the city differently, not just as a commercial hub. To introduce you to culture in the Cameroonian style with international ambitions, come and discover Colonne Pascale by Pascale Marthine Tayou, Pirogue Céleste by Hervé Youmbi, l'Arbre à Palabres by Frederick Keiff or Borne-Fontaine by Daniele Diwouta-Kotto. The latter is one of the Douala architects most committed to African architectural innovation

Doual'art
87, place du Gouvernement

content.title: Limbe Wildlife Centre: out to protect nature

introduction.small: The mission of the zoo is to make the population aware of the need to preserve the exceptional diversity of the flora and fauna of Cameroon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Limbe Wildlife Centre: out to protect nature

paragraphs.text:
Established in 1993, the Limbe Wildlife Centre (LWC) or Limbe Zoological Park is a collaboration between the Government of Cameroon and the Pandrillus foundation. Located in Bota, 50 metres from the Botanical Garden, it covers an area of nearly 44 hectares. Though the original purpose of the zoo was to create a sanctuary for chimpanzees, it now houses and gives first aid to 15 species of primates rescued from poachers including gorillas, mandrills, baboons, mangabey, giant chimpanzees, guenons... but also crocodiles, pythons and even a turtle!

Along the beautifully appointed walkways, take the time to read the small explanatory signs in front of each enclosure and make the most of the observatory, all special touches that make visiting the zoo, open to the public from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., a particularly pleasant time. Near the entrance, an exhibition is open to all and, inside the park, you can enjoy a refreshment to cool off or have a sandwich at the little snack bar. Note that the weather being particularly humid, it is recommended to be careful on the often slippery wooden planks.

Limbe Wildlife Centre (LWC)
Botanical Garden Road
Limbé

+237 698 87 70 02

http://limbewildlife.org/

content.title: La Grande Marmite spices up local products

introduction.small: Local flavours are being cooked with love inside La Grand Marmite.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Grande Marmite spices up local products

paragraphs.text:
The friendly setting of this archetypal Cameroonian restaurant gives you a foretaste of local flavour. Like the ‘Chicken DG', the national dish of Cameroon (‘DG' is short for General Director in French), served with plantain fries, vegetables and condiments, which is a delicious dish dominated by aromas of ginger, onions and hot pepper. Less spicy but just as flavourful, the ndomba fried pork rested en papillote with banana leaves is both crispy and soft. Just as nice, the braised fish is cooked in the most local tradition.

La Grande Marmite is a fine local stop that does not however object to paying homage to Dakar and its kedjenou chicken (braised chicken covered of attiéké leaves). Once again, a really spicy dish. A true delight on the tastebuds.

La Grande Marmite

content.title: Hilton: international style in Yaoundé

introduction.small: This palace in the centre of Yaoundé won the title ‘Best Luxury City Hotel' in 2015 in Cameroon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hilton: international style in Yaoundé

paragraphs.text:
If Cameroonian hotels are not yet up to international standards, this five-star hotel demonstrates that such is the ambition. Located in the district of ministries and embassies, the Hilton has all the services that international travellers expect. Its rooms are spacious, comfortable and available in all categories, and they enjoy excellent views over the city. Do not miss watching night fall on Yaoundé from your balcony: at that time of day, the clamour diminishes and another city appears. The family suites are a welcome option when travelling with children. Several meeting rooms are available for businessmen, and the gym is particularly well equipped. After tasting grilled chicken at Chez Hélène, a local restaurant in the neighbourhood, you will enjoy any of the four excellent restaurants of the hotel and the panoramic bar.

content.title: Cathedral of Saints Peter and Paul: a little byzantine something

introduction.small: In the heart of the city, the beautiful Cathedral of Saints Peter and Paul stands upon the ruins of Douala's first catholic church.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cathedral of Saints Peter and Paul: a little byzantine something

paragraphs.text:
When standing at the roundabout on the boulevard de la Liberté, you will see the cathedral's thin outline. Dedicated to the apostles St Peter and St Paul, it was built in 1936 by French Spiritans fathers right in front of the city cemetery. Once stood there the first catholic church built by German Pallotins fathers at the end of the 19th century.

Two twin towers surround the central front. The various columns and the dome give the edifice a byzantine look. But look closely and you shall also notice neo-roman architecture, especially on its front. Nowadays, the cathedral is head office to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Douala, which covers the coastline, western province and some of the central areas of the country.

Cathedral of Saints Peter and Paul, Douala
Rue Joss (in line with the boulevard de la Liberté)
Douala

content.title: Kribi: a long beach with white sand and waterfalls

introduction.small: Head to Kribi, two hours away from Douala, with small fishing villages and white sand beaches.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kribi: a long beach with white sand and waterfalls

paragraphs.text:
Time stands still on this coastline bordered with coconut trees. Even if the Douala residents make Kribi and Londii home for the weekend, there are no motorboats or windsurf boards on the water, just a handful of dugout canoes. The residents of the coast, the Batanga, Mabi and Bagyeli watch attentively over the ecological respect of their beaches, as do the pygmies, at one time hailing from Kribi, but today residents of the forest that they also protect. In Kribi and Londji, authenticity and tranquillity describe the areas along the 10-kilometre white sand beach.

Between your stretches in the sun, make sure to visit the Lobé waterfalls. It is the only place in the world where a coastal river arrives in cascades in the Atlantic. This natural spectacle is considered sacred. In Ebodjé, you will see the marine turtles and on the beaches of Grand Batanga you will lunch in beach huts—fish, shellfish and the famous large sea shrimp are all to be tasted here.

content.title: Blackitude Museum: a trip into African culture

introduction.small: At the heart of downtown Yaoundé, this museum is a testimony to the cultural and artistic richness of Cameroon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Blackitude Museum: a trip into African culture

paragraphs.text:
Her Majesty Fo Nab Ngo I NANA Agnès Sunjio held an important royal treasure passed on by her father (and other Kings of West Cameroon). She founded the Blackitude Museum in 1998 to preserve a large part of the Cameroonian artistic heritage.

This institution now gathers more than 2070 artworks of various collections, such as wooden and bronze statues, traditional costumes and masks, and furniture. The museum teaches, values and spreads arts and culture in various themes.

African art is now considered one of the most stunning and diverse in the world. A visit is therefore needed to admire the beauty, style and finesse of these creations, which are the expression of peoples' beliefs.

The museum now expands into social and humanitarian activities, helping the poor and idle by teaching them a craft.

Musée Camerounais de la Blackitude
Downtown (across the Boulevard du 20 mai)
Yaoundé

+237 222 22 03 00

www.museeblackitude.org

content.title: Mount Cameroon: hike up the second highest summit of Africa

introduction.small: At 4,090 metres, 70 kilometres from Douala, the climb up this still active volcano is an adventure that lasts two days and spans forests and savannahs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mount Cameroon: hike up the second highest summit of Africa

paragraphs.text:
Every year in February, the ascension of Mount Cameroon or Mount Fako, also called ‘the chariot of the gods', is one of the major sporting events of the country. This mountain race, one of the hardest in the world, brings together some 500 competitors. But you can also choose to make the hike at another time of year and at a rhythm conducive to making the most of the sublime landscapes. Once past the city of Buéa, where the Ecotourism Office will have provided you with all the necessary information, you cross manioc fields, as well as sugarcane and pineapple plantations. Roughly one day of walking brings you to Mann Springs. You can then wander through forests of rare woods, from the wenge, sapelli and iroko then choose one of the paths through the savannah that remains incredibly green and flowered, even in the dry season. From here you can approach one of the numerous craters—there are more than 600. You will perhaps have the chance to see a representative of the Bakweri people come and place an offering. After spending a night in a refuge, you can explore the former German colonial village guided by its roofs that shine under the Cameroonian sun.

Ecotourism Office
Buéa

+237 233 32 26 56

content.title: Buea Mountain Hotel: a country lodge

introduction.small: In Buea, at the foot of a volcano, this hotel has old-fashioned British charm and encourages a break at the edge of the pool.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Buea Mountain Hotel: a country lodge

paragraphs.text:
Knowing the English taste for climbing and hiking, it is not surprising that the British colonial administration built this establishment in 1952. In fact, it has retained a very 1950s aura, with an ounce of military style and makes one think more of a motel than a traditional hotel. In addition to its proximity to the volcano, its location an hour from Douala makes it a perfect home base, either to relax away from it all, or as a stop on a trip around the country.

The exotic garden and the outdoor pool of Buea Mountain Hotel will allow you to put the two hours spent on the bush taxi ride from Douala behind you. Rooms are comfortable and have everything that you would expect. If you prefer peace and quiet, you can also book one of the 30 small cottages. For dining, the two proposed cuisines, African and international, are both hearty and copious. Remember that they are made to satisfy the valiant hikers of Mount Cameroon!

Buea Mountain Hotel
Federal Quarter
Buéa

+237 233 32 22 99

www.mountainhotelcameroon.com

Rooms: from 21,590 XAF

content.title: Pongo-Songo: Chimpanzee island

introduction.small: A dozen years ago, Patricia Leschaeve created an animal reserve on this small island on the Sanaga River for animals threatened by deforestation and poaching.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pongo-Songo: Chimpanzee island

paragraphs.text:
While the UN Environmental Programme has protected the chimpanzees of the Douala-Edéa reserve since 2001, poaching and deforestation at times still have disastrous consequences on this small primate community. The Papaye France Association welcomes the wounded and orphans, teaching them to live on this island just as their parents had done in the nearby forest.

After a two-hour drive in a bush taxi, you are welcome to visit this refuge for a full day. Neither a zoo nor a tourist attraction, it is not equipped as such and so it is best to arrive with your own snacks, water and even some fuel for the small boat that will bring you across the river. Fruits and honey for the chimpanzees are welcome too. Once on the island, you can speak with the volunteers that will explain their activities. Live a child's dream playing with Jojo, Pistache or Cacahuète and walk them about on a strip of sand. They are affectionate, but also clever. Don't be surprised if they play a trick on you!

https://www.facebook.com/PapayeFrance/

content.title: Douala: the Museum of the sea and rivers

introduction.small: Douala is the top Cameroonian port. It makes sense that this commercial capital would have a museum tracing its history and that of maritime trade.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Douala: the Museum of the sea and rivers

paragraphs.text:
After having been ravaged by fire, this museum has just re-opened and is the pride of Douala. When you say ‘Cameroon' you say ‘ocean'. Indeed the Portuguese came from the sea, they who gave the country its name. ‘Cameroon' is derived from ‘rio dos camarões', the ‘river of the shrimp' in Portuguese. Shrimp were, and remain, very abundant at the delta of the Wouri River.

The museum traces the history of men of the sea and rivers from the different ports of Cameroon—Douala, Kribi, Limbe—as well as trade with Chad and the Central African Republic. The many exhibits through photographs, paintings, sculptures, maps and videos allow you to better understand the Cameroon landscape and its evolution over the years. You will learn a lot about traditional and modern fishing­­––from the oldest canoes to the current containers, not to mention the brand new exhibits on storms and a marine navigation simulator.

Douala Maritime Museum
Direction Générale du Conseil National des Chargeurs du Cameroun (CNCC)
Rue de l'Hôpital
Bonanjo
Douala

+237 233 42 21 65

http://museemaritime.cm/new/

content.title: La Villa des Fées: a river runs through it

introduction.small: The house of Henriette and Émile is a peaceful getaway with a view of the natural and untamed riverbanks of the Wouri.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Villa des Fées: a river runs through it

paragraphs.text:
You are in one of the four historic districts of the city. Here, the noise was lost on the way through, replaced by the pleasure of hearing birds singing. The days are punctuated by the tides, in the estuary of the Wouri, prompting a quiet meditation.

Henriette, the hostess who is passionate about interior design, has good taste. She transformed this old colonial house into a refined, hospitable and caring place to stay. Her only concern is for your well-being and so she constantly offers you all that you need for a pleasant sojourn. Each of the six rooms lives up to its reputation. Spacious, comfortable and cosy, they feature a private bathroom, a flat screen TV and free WiFi. Public areas have been transformed into lounges, each with a different theme for a break, a talk, eat or drink, with pleasant areas for everyone. Douala's finest meet here for lunch on the terrace or dinner in the dining room.

La Villa des Fées
Unnamed Road
Douala

+237 699 02 10 73

Rooms: from 120,500 XAF

content.title: The White House Restaurant asserts itself in red

introduction.small: The White House Restaurant has become one of Douala's major stops.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The White House Restaurant asserts itself in red

paragraphs.text:
At the corner of King Akwa avenue and Pasteur Lottin Samé Street, this openwork restaurant favours the colour red on tables and chairs, which are reminders of the clay soil at the heart of the country.

The restaurant is open 7/7, from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m. It burned down in a fire in 2012 but never closed, thanks to its strong reputation and the clientele's sympathy.

At the White House, African dishes and grilled food are enjoyed as a buffet. We favour the braised chicken Cameroonian style, marinated in local spices and condiments before being precooked then grilled. A special flavour that will leave you longing for more!

To enjoy this fine cooking and service, we strongly advise you to make a booking.

White House Restaurant
84, rue Pasteur Lottin Samé
Douala

+237 33 43 10 95

https://www.facebook.com/White-House-Restaurant-463277827113487/

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Douala
content.introduction:
Located in an intertropical convergence zone, Cameroon offers two types of climate, tropical and equatorial. Douala is located on the coastline. The rainy season extends from June to October, the worst rainfall happening in August, therefore to be avoided. Temperate and dry, December to February is the best season to discover the area.

Around Yaoundé, the dry season is longer, from November to March. To visit in the best conditions, avoid the months of September-October. Heavy rain floods the land and makes driving around very uncertain.

airports.title: Douala International Airport and Yaoundé-Nsimalen International Airport
airports.description:
Douala International Airport

The Douala International Airport is located 7 kilometres (4 miles) from Douala's city centre.
  • One terminal (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Douala and back:
  • By car:
    • Access via the N3 road.
      Two parking lots at the airport, outdoor and at basement level, with capacities of 334 and 134 vehicles. Both enjoy baggage handling services. XAF 600 per 2 hours, XAF 5,000 per 12 to 24 hours (outdoor) and XAF 700 per hour, XAF 10,000 per 12 to 24 hours (basement).
    • Rentals: a car rental company is located in the arrivals hall.
  • By hotel shuttle:
    Some large hotels organize their own shuttle service to and from the airport. Check with your hotel ahead of time.
  • By taxi:
    Yellow taxis are available at the ranks outside the airport to take you to Douala's city centre. Allow for a 15-minute trip and a XAF 3,500 fare. Before departure, you may also ask your hotel to arrange for a shuttle transfer or a PHV to pick you up. For all transportation within the city, besides traditional bush taxis taking multiple customers for varying fares, two private companies with AC cars were recently launched in Cameroon. They can be reached locally, so we advise you to go through your hotel to reserve a taxi. Fares to downtown Douala run about XAF 10,000.
  • Services: ATMs, VIP lounges, newspaper stands duty-free shops and free Internet access (Wi-Fi) in the airport.
  • Website: https://www.aeroport-douala.com/en/index_en.php
  • Telephone: +237 233 42 35 77

Yaoundé-Nsimalen International Airport

The Yaoundé-Nsimalen airport is located 22 kilometres (14 miles) south-west of Yaoundé's city centre.
  • Two terminals
    • T1
    • T2 (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Yaoundé and back:
  • By car:
    • Access via N2 Joseph Tchooungui Akoa.
      There is an outdoor car park at the airport, with a 578 capacity. XAF 650 per 2 hours, XAF 4,500 per 12 to 24 hours.
    • Rentals: a car rental company is located in the arrivals hall.
  • Hotel shuttles:
    Some large hotels organize their own shuttle services to and from the airport. Check with your hotel ahead of time.
  • Taxi:
    Yellow taxis are available at the ranks outside the airport to take you to Yaoundé's city centre. Allow for a 30-minute trip and a XAF 3,500 fare. Before departure, you may also ask your hotel to arrange for a shuttle transfer or a PHV to pick you up. For all transportation within the city, besides traditional bush taxis taking multiple customers for varying fares, two private companies with AC cars were recently launched in Cameroon. They can be reached locally, so we advise you to go through your hotel to reserve a taxi. Fares to downtown Douala run about XAF 10,000.
  • Services: ATMs, a restaurant, newspaper stands, a post office, handicraft, duty-free shops and free Internet access (Wi-Fi) in the airport.
  • Website: www.adcsa.aero/

Telephone: +237 222 21 22 21

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Douala
transportation.description: Uncertain bus routes, heavy traffic and non-existent car parks in some neighbourhoods: getting around Cameroon's two major cities can be a hassle. We advise you to use a taxi.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description:
There is no proper Tourist Information centre in Cameroon. For information on how to prepare your trip, we advise you to get in touch with the Tourist Information Centre for Europe in Paris, France.

Douala is the commercial and economic capital of Cameroon, while Yaoundé is the political one. Ministries and administrations are therefore all in Yaoundé. It may be possible to get in touch with the Department of Tourism and Leisure to find more information.

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Douala and Yaoundé count several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
Vaccination for yellow fever is mandatory before flying to Cameroon. Proof of vaccination is required upon arrival.

It is recommended to have updated vaccines as usually required (diphtheria, typhoid, tetanus, polio, hepatitis A and B). Vaccination against rabies and meningococcal meningitis may also be advised.

For more information, contact the Air France Vaccination Centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description:
To maintain good hygiene, it is recommended:

  • not to use ice cubes made from tap water, not to drink fresh fruit juice, not to eat uncooked vegetables or unpeeled fruits
  • not to eat insufficiently cooked food, especially meat, fish and milk
  • to regularly and carefully wash your hands

information.title: Water
information.description: It is recommended to drink only from sealed bottled water.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few useful phrases in French and English, which are the two official languages in Cameroon.
phrases: I don't understand: Je ne comprends pas
What time is it ?: Quelle heure est-il ?
How much is (…)?: Quel est le prix de (…) ?
Where can I find (…)?: Où puis-je trouver (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: Où puis-je acheter (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Douala
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Cameroon each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 1: New Year's Day and Independence Day (national)
events.description: In Cameroon, January 1<sup>st</sup> is a double occasion: the country enters the new year, but also celebrates its Independence, proclaimed on January 1<sup>st</sup>, 1960. Lively atmosphere all around, especially in large cities like Douala and Yaoundé.

events.title: February 11: Youth Day (national)
events.description: Cameroon celebrates the youths and students. School parades and sometimes public shows take place in the streets, dancing schools, choirs and sports clubs to express the nation's talents.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (national)
events.description: Labour Day is a public holiday for all Cameroonians. This day is spent on parades and worker marches.

events.title: May 8: International Women's Day (national)
events.description: Cameroonian women are very attached to Women's Day. Official celebrations, women parades, marches: women are the talk of the town, especially in large cities, where many nightclubs are reserved for them. Gentlemen, on that day you will stay outside!

events.title: May 20: National Day
events.description: Cameroon celebrates its foundation, and the transition from a federal state to a unitary one. Public marches and parades are a reason for popular rejoicing.

events.title: August 15: Assumption (national)
events.description: Every year, Cameroonians feverishly and grandiloquently celebrate the assumption of the Virgin Mary into Heaven.

events.title: First week of December: Ngondo (only in the Douala area)
events.description: The Ngondo takes place for a week and is held by the Sawa (coastal peoples). Miss Douala contest, dancing shows, pirogue races and many other activities follow the ceremony during which town inhabitants commune with their ancestors and the water spirits.

events.title: December 25: Christmas Day (national)
events.description: Cameroonians celebrate the birth of Christ. In a country where religious traditions are widespread, services are usually followed by family meals.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Cameroon
administrativeProcedures.description:
A valid visa is mandatory in Cameroon (tourist, business or long-stay).

Before entering the country, a tourist visa may be delivered by Cameroonian authorities to foreigners who travel for leisure. It cannot exceed 30 days, and cannot be renewed, but multiple entrances and exits are possible.

To obtain a tourist visa for Cameroon, you must meet several prerequisites. You may find more by going to the Cameroonian Consulate in France, writing them or visiting the website: consgencamparis.com/

We recommend that you leave certified photocopies of your ID cards at your hotel or at your friends, so that consular services may identify you in case of loss or theft.

To travel serenely in Cameroon, follow the travel advice of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs:

www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/cameroon/

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: There is no Daylight Savings Time in Cameroon.
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
Tipping is customary in Cameroon. If the service is appreciated, a good rule of thumb is to leave an extra 5 to 15%. Please note that tipping is the only income for some professionals such as baggage handlers at the airport.
